metadata.title: Advice for the 2nd week of VMCSP 2021

extra.html:
Advice

Advice for the 2nd week of VMCSP 2021

Answers from our staff to your questions!

Staff, 2nd week

Q: I’m having a lot of trouble deciding what classes to take. How should I choose?

A: The first thing you should do is take one of Susan’s set theory classes. You will be quickly indoctrinated into the cult of the Axiom of Choice. After that, the Axiom will make all your decisions for you. You will never again need to worry.

Q: Ahh! I’ve been getting all these messages from Bear. I don’t like bears very much--once, one followed me on a big hike and kept on looking at me funny. How do I avoid being eaten by a bear?

A: If you’ve seen any of those funny little “Do Feed the Bears” signs floating around, you are in bear-infected territory! Take out your trust Bear Repellant, fill out your Log Table, avoid Staff (who are not Bears, but who may be Bears), and give any bears you see some Cocoa Puff Brownie Crunch.


Q: Hi Mathtown Chronicle Advice. I’ve been trying to attend six classes at once, but I’ve been having trouble keeping up. There’s just so many interesting things happening, and I don’t want to miss out! How can I continue learning from every single thing happening at Mathcamp?

A: One easy way to keep up with everything at Mathcamp is to get a Time Turner. That way you can go to every class and also go to every event. Another easy way to deal with this issue is to choose the class you are most interested in and attend only it, since that way you don’t have to deal with the lesser classes.


Q: I was trying to navigate Mathtown, and I have been seeing these Sphinx-related signs everywhere. What do they mean? What do they want from me?

A: The Sphinx signs were put there by the Sphinx of Vexillomancy, who uses the signs to indicate that you should fear the locations. The Sphinx prefers that you leave offerings of completed log tables at the entrance to the locations.


Q: There are so many interesting classes, projects, and talks happening at Mathcamp, combined with a bunch of creative events at all times of day. I always worry that I’m missing out! How do I make sure I am maximizing the amount of fun I have at Mathcamp?

A: FOMO is a common fear at Mathcamp, and you need to recognize that you can’t do everything. The math is super interesting and there’s a lot of cool events, but you also need to get enough sleep if you want to enjoy either of those. A good tip for making the most out of Mathcamp is to explore. Talk to new people, go to events you normally wouldn’t go to, and take classes in different areas of math. You won’t regret it.


Q: My carriage is going to turn back into a pumpkin at midnight, how can I make the most out of the time before then?

A: Ask a different advice column.


Q: What sort of commentary should I leave in my yearbook entry?

A: Some types of clever yearbook entries include jokes, predictions of the future that you can ensure come true, such as a particular event occurring in the talent show, and poems or creative works dedicated to Mathcamp. Alternatively, one could use a yearbook entry to give shoutouts to the things you enjoyed most about Mathcamp, such as the classes and events in it.
